member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Cell.Formula
member.summary: Gets or sets a formula of the .
member.remarks:
A formula string always begins with an equal sign (=). And please always use comma(,) as parameters delimeter, such as "=SUM(A1, E1, H2)".
User can set any formula in Excel designer file. Aspose.Excel will keep all the formulas. If user use this property to set a formula to a cell, major part of Excel built-in functions is supported. And more is coming. If you have any special need for Excel built-in functions, please let us know.
Now Excel built-in functions supported by Aspose.Excel:
[A]
ABS, ACOS, ACOSH, AND, ASC, ASIN, ASINH, ATAN, ATAN2, ATANH, AVEDEV, AVERAGE
[C]
CEILING, CHAR, CODE, COLUMN, COLUMNS, COMBIN, CONCATENATE, CORREL, COS, COSH, COUNT, COUNTA, COUNTBLANK, COUNTIF
[D]
DATE, DATEVALUE, DAVERAGE, DAY, DAYS360, DCOUNT, DCOUNTA, DEGREES, DGET, DMAX, DMIN, DOLLAR, DPRODUCT,
DSTDEV, DSTDEVP, DSUM, DVAR, DVARP
[E]
EVEN, EXACT, EXP
[F]
FACT, FALSE, FIND, FIXED, FLOOR, FV
[H]
HLOOKUP, HOUR, HYPERLINK
[I]
IF, INDEX, INDIRECT, INT, ISBLANK, ISNA, ISNUMBER
[L]
LEFT, LEN, LINEST, LN, LOG, LOG10, LOOKUP, LOWER
[M]
MATCH, MAX, MEDIAN, MID, MIN, MINUTE, MOD, MONTH
[N]
NOT, NOW, NPV
[O]
ODD, OFFSET,OR
[P]
PI, PMT, POWER, PRODUCT, PV
[R]
RADIANS, RAND, RANK, REPLACE, REPT, RIGHT, ROUND, ROUNDDOWN, ROUNDUP, ROW, ROWS
[S]
SEARCH, SECOND, SIGN, SIN, SINH, SQRT, STDEV, STDEVP, SUBSTITUTE, SUBTOTAL, SUM, SUMIF, SUMPRODUCT, SUMSQ, SUMX2MY2, SUMX2PY2, SUMXMY2
[T]
T, TAN, TANH, TEXT, TIME, TODAY, TRIM, TRUE, TRUNC
[U]
UPPER
[V]
VALUE, VLOOKUP
[W]
WEEKDAY, WIDECHAR
[Y]
YEAR

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Cells.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets cell items within the worksheet
member.param: The zero based index of the element.
member.value: The element at the specified index.
member.remarks: This is the indexer for the Cells class. Gets the cell element at the specified index.

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Cells.Item(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the element at the specified cell row index and column index.

example.code:
[C#]
Cells cells = excel.Worksheets[0].Cells; Cell cell = cells[0, 0]; //Gets the cell at "A1"
[Visual Basic]
Dim cells As Cells = excel.Worksheets(0).Cells Dim cell As Cell = cells(0,0) 'Gets the cell at "A1"

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Cells.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the element at the specified cell name.
member.param: Cell name,including its column letter and row number, for example A5.

example.code:
[C#]
Cells cells = excel.Worksheets[0].Cells; Cell cell = cells["A1"]; //Gets the cell at "A1"
[Visual Basic]
Dim cells As Cells = excel.Worksheets(0).Cells Dim cell As Cell = cells("A1") 'Gets the cell at "A1"

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Chart.FirstSliceAngle

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Chart.Floor
member.summary: Returns a object that represents the walls of a 3-D chart.
member.remarks: This property doesn't apply to 3-D pie charts.

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Chart.Walls
member.summary: Returns a object that represents the walls of a 3-D chart.
member.remarks: This property doesn't apply to 3-D pie charts.

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Chart.Rotation
member.summary: Represents the rotation of the 3-D chart view (the rotation of the plot area around the z-axis, in degrees).
member.remarks: The value of this property must be from 0 to 360, except for 3-D bar charts, where the value must be from 0 to 44. The default value is 20. Applies only to 3-D charts.

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Chart.Elevation
member.summary: Represents the elevation of the 3-D chart view, in degrees.
member.remarks: The chart elevation is the height at which you view the chart, in degrees. The default is 15 for most chart types. The value of this property must be between -90 and 90, except for 3-D bar charts, where it must be between 0 and 44.

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Chart.DepthPercent
member.summary: Represents the depth of a 3-D chart as a percentage of the chart width (between 20 and 2000 percent).

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Chart.MajorGridLines
member.summary: Represents major gridlines on a chart axis.
member.remarks: /// NOTE: This member is now obsolete. Instead, you should use for the same purpose. It will be removed 12 months later since release 2.7.1 in December 2004. Aspose apologizes for any inconvenience you may have experienced.

member.name: M:Aspose.Excel.Excel.CalculateFormula
member.summary: Calculates the result of formulas.
member.remarks:
This method is only supported in Enterprise edition. It does not support formulas with external links to other files.
In an evaluation copy, a random string may be added in each worksheet. That may change the calculation result. In a licensed copy, all will be fine.
Now Excel built-in functions supported in this method:
[A]
ABS, AND, AVERAGE
[C]
CEILING, COLUMN, COLUMNS, CORREL, CONCATENATE, COUNT, COUNTA
[D]
DATE, DAY, DOLLAR
[F]
FIND
[H]
HLOOKUP
[I]
IF, INT, ISERROR
[L]
LEN, LINEST
[M]
MAX, MID, MIN, MOD, MONTH
[O]
OR
[P]
POWER
[R]
ROUND, ROW, ROWS
[S]
SUM, SUMPRODUCT
[T]
TIME, TODAY
[U]
UPPER
[V]
VALUE
[Y]
YEAR
And Aspose.Excel supports the following add-in functions:
MCORRELS, REGRESSN

Saving in Aspose.Pdf.Xml Format
Please note that some formatting specified in spreadsheets might be lost when converting into Aspose.Pdf.Xml. For example, images, charts and other drawing objects will be lost. Both Aspose.Excel and Aspose.Pdf development teams are working hard to enhance MS Excel to PDF conversion and support as many features of spreadsheets as possible.

member.name: T:Aspose.Excel.License
member.summary: Provides methods to license the component.
member.example:
In this example, an attempt will be made to find a license file named MyLicense.lic in the folder that contains the component, in the folder that contains the calling assembly, in the folder of the entry assembly and then in the embedded resources of the calling assembly.
[C#]
License license = new License(); license.SetLicense("MyLicense.lic");
[Visual Basic]
Dim license As license = New license License.SetLicense("MyLicense.lic")

member.name: M:Aspose.Excel.License.#ctor

member.example:
In this example, an attempt will be made to find a license file named MyLicense.lic in the folder that contains the component, in the folder that contains the calling assembly, in the folder of the entry assembly and then in the embedded resources of the calling assembly.

[Visual Basic]

member.name: M:Aspose.Excel.License.SetLicense(System.String)
member.summary: Licenses the component.
member.param: Can be a full or short file name or name of an embedded resource. Use an empty string to switch to evaluation mode.

remarks.p: Tries to find the license in the following locations:
2. The folder of the component assembly.
3. The folder of the client's calling assembly.
4. The folder of the entry assembly.
5. An embedded resource in the client's calling assembly.

member.summary: Represents if the deletion of columns is allowed on a protected worksheet.
member.remarks: The columns containing the cells to be deleted must be unlocked when the sheet is protected, and "Select unlocked cells" option must be enabled.

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Worksheets.BuiltInDocumentProperties
member.summary: Returns a DocumentProperties collection that represents all the built-in document properties of the spreadsheet.
member.remarks:
A new property cannot be added to built-in document properties list. You can only get a built-in property and change its value. The following is the built-in properties name list:
Title
Subject
Author
Keywords
Comments
Template
Last Author
Revision Number
Application Name
Last Print Date
Creation Date
Last Save Time
Total Editing Time
Number of Pages
Number of Words
Number of Characters
Security
Category
Format
Manager
Company
Number of Bytes
Number of Lines
Number of Paragraphs
Number of Slides
Number of Notes
Number of Hidden Slides
Number of Multimedia Clips

member.name: P:Aspose.Excel.Worksheets.CustomDocumentProperties
member.summary: Returns a DocumentProperties collection that represents all the custom document properties of the spreadsheet.

example.code:
[C#] excel.Worksheets.CustomDocumentProperties.Add("Checked by", "Jane");
[Visual Basic] excel.Worksheets.CustomDocumentProperties.Add("Checked by", "Jane")
